intro: Astragalus hirsutus subsp. paraglobosus, commonly known as the hairy milkvetch, is a perennial herb native to the western United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its hairy stems and small, yellowish flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid or semi-arid environments. Its leaves are compound, with several pairs of leaflets, and it produces legume pods that contain small, rounded seeds. This subspecies is part of the Fabaceae family, known for its nitrogen-fixing ability through symbiotic relationships with soil bacteria.
